title: Exploring the Potential of Human-LLM Synergy in Advancing Qualitative Analysis: A Case Study on Mental-Illness Stigma
abstract: Qualitative analysis is a challenging, yet crucial aspect of advancing research in the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI). Recent studies show that large language models (LLMs) can perform qualitative coding within existing schemes, but their potential for collaborative human-LLM discovery and new insight generation in qualitative analysis is still underexplored. To bridge this gap and advance qualitative analysis by harnessing the power of LLMs, we propose CHALET, a novel methodology that leverages the human-LLM collaboration paradigm to facilitate conceptualization and empower qualitative research. The CHALET approach involves LLM-supported data collection, performing both human and LLM deductive coding to identify disagreements, and performing collaborative inductive coding on these disagreement cases to derive new conceptual insights. We validated the effectiveness of CHALET through its application to the attribution model of mental-illness stigma, uncovering implicit stigmatization themes on cognitive, emotional and behavioral dimensions. We discuss the implications for future research, methodology, and the transdisciplinary opportunities CHALET presents for the HCI community and beyond.

sections.text:
Qualitative analysis (Busetto et al., 2020  ###reference_b19###) is crucial for HCI and social science, offering benefits such as conceptualizing phenomena, understanding human behavior (Ong et al., 2020  ###reference_b127###), and expanding theoretical frameworks (Fisher and Aguinis, 2017  ###reference_b53###). It provides a solid theoretical base to grasp the societal and ethical impacts of new technologies, guiding their responsible development (Ameen et al., 2022  ###reference_b6###). The importance of qualitative data in HCI research is growing (Warner et al., 2019  ###reference_b164###), driven by the need to deeply understand human-AI interactions through detailed data analysis (Jardine et al., 2024  ###reference_b90###). However, qualitative analysis struggles with challenges such as the difficulty of managing large datasets and risking bias (Collier and Mahoney, 1996  ###reference_b29###). The qualitative coding approach (Busetto et al., 2020  ###reference_b19###; W. Bradley McKibben and Wahesh, 2022  ###reference_b162###) is vital, although it faces issues of bias (Collier and Mahoney, 1996  ###reference_b29###), replication difficulties (Leeson et al., 2019  ###reference_b101###), and being labor-intensive (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###), especially with large datasets.
###figure_1### ###figure_2### This figure provides an overview of the Collaborative Human-LLM Synergistic Analysis Extending Theoretical Framework, illustrating its main components and how they interact within the context of elaborating theories.
LLMs, such as ChatGPT111https://chat.openai.com/  ###reference_chat.openai.com/### and Llama (Touvron et al., 2023  ###reference_b158###), offer the potential to streamline the labor-intensive qualitative analysis process. As prominent examples of generative AI, these models can understand natural language instructions and generate human-like text outputs, making them well-suited for this task. Recognizing this potential, LLMs are increasingly used for preliminary qualitative coding tasks, facilitating both inductive (Islam and Goldwasser, 2024  ###reference_b88###) and deductive (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###) approaches.
Although recent studies highlight the capability of LLMs in deductive coding within existing coding schemes (Hou et al., 2024a  ###reference_b83###; Kirsten et al., 2024  ###reference_b96###), their ability to uncover novel findings and generate insights that facilitate qualitative analysis from these coding schemes remains underexplored.
Existing research mainly quantifies LLM-human coder agreement (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###; Chew et al., 2023  ###reference_b23###), focusing on model performance rather than investigating causes of suboptimal results, i.e., cases where the model’s output diverges from the human-generated code. This emphasis on quantitative measures overshadows the importance of qualitative analysis of the discrepancies (Kirsten et al., 2024  ###reference_b96###), leading to a gap in understanding and interpreting instances where LLMs differ from human judgment. Without a detailed examination of the inconsistencies between coders, it hinders the understanding and further derivation of new theoretical insights.
After acknowledging the gap, efforts to investigate the discordance between humans and LLMs for deductive coding have been proposed, focusing on refining existing code definitions to improve qualitative coding (Zambrano et al., 2023  ###reference_b173###; Dai et al., 2023a  ###reference_b37###).
While refining code definitions based on discrepancies is a step in the right direction, it is not sufficient to derive qualitative advancements (Fisher and Aguinis, 2017  ###reference_b53###). These initiatives have not thoroughly assessed the overall effectiveness of the coding frameworks in place or fully leveraged the potential of LLMs to contribute to deeper conceptual development.
LLM-assisted deductive coding has the potential to go beyond simple code refinement and open avenues for deeper integration with conceptual development through qualitative coding, as LLMs have been shown to stimulate research creativity (Mirowski et al., 2023  ###reference_b120###) and detect linguistic subtleties as well as latent arguments (Yan et al., 2024  ###reference_b171###), possibly revealing new perspectives that could enrich and deepen the qualitative analysis process. Thus, further exploration of how LLMs can contribute to qualitative analysis and conceptualization is warranted, as they might offer deeper and nuanced interpretations.
To explore the potential of LLM-assisted qualitative analysis in fostering richer conceptualization, we thereby propose a methodological framework called  CHALET (Collaborative Human-LLM AnaLysis for Empowering Conceptualization in QualiTative Research), which aims to promote qualitative analysis by employing an LLM-assisted hybrid coding process, following three steps: data collection, deductive coding, and inductive coding. Figure 1  ###reference_### illustrates the above steps. LLMs play a crucial role in all steps of the framework: 1) facilitating the collection of multi-dimensional data through the promotion of self-disclosure and 2) enabling LLM-assisted qualitative coding. Uniquely, our framework focuses on discrepancies between human and LLM coding. By analyzing instances where LLM coding diverges from human coding, we performed in-depth inductive coding with LLM support to uncover new themes and insights. This approach, naturally possessing a synergistic human-LLM collaboration paradigm, adeptly integrates the inductive ability, social awareness and reasoning strengths of human researchers with the efficient data processing (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###) and extensive knowledge retrieval capabilities of LLMs (Linzbach et al., 2023  ###reference_b110###). It allows us to derive new conceptual insights through qualitative analysis, leveraging the unique perspectives offered by human-LLM collaboration.
###figure_3### We assessed our framework with a case study on the stigma attribution model of mental illness (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###). This model, linking causes attributed to behaviors with mental illness stigma, connects responsibility perceptions to stigma-driven emotions and actions (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###). Emerging concepts such as microaggression (Gibson et al., 2023  ###reference_b59###) and mental illness invalidation (Gonzales et al., 2015a  ###reference_b63###) necessitate a deeper qualitative analysis of the attribution model to reflect contemporary social stigma perspectives. Our human-LLM synergistic framework, applied here, integrates these views, enhancing understanding of social stigma and its conceptual insights. We used this framework to analyze conversations from 1,002 participants, revealing new insights into cognitive, emotional, and behavioral responses, and identified linguistic features and prompting techniques that affect LLM coding of psychological constructs, demonstrating our framework’s ability to advance qualitative analysis.
Our work contributes in several ways. Firstly, we introduce an LLM-assisted framework to enhance conceptualization, using an attribution model of mental illness stigma to demonstrate its effectiveness in advancing qualitative analysis and providing insights through human-LLM collaboration. This method addresses issues like bias, reproducibility, and time efficiency. Secondly, we offer a new perspective on structuring human-LLM collaboration for qualitative research, discussing future method implications, practical LLM uses, and the pros and cons of LLM adoption, potentially enriching future theoretical work. Finally, we present a systematic method for LLMs to analyze psychological constructs, exploring prompt design, and identifying performance-limiting factors. This supports the creation of psychological datasets with LLM assistance (Demszky et al., 2023  ###reference_b41###), merging extensive language data collection with LLM-assisted coding to produce high-quality and psychologically relevant datasets, helping future research.

Qualitative analysis is a crucial research methodology in various fields, with qualitative coding being one of its essential techniques. Qualitative coding involves the process of categorizing and labeling data to identify patterns, themes, and hypotheses. Deductive coding (Fereday and Muir-Cochrane, 2006a  ###reference_b51###) applies predefined codes derived from existing theories, while inductive coding (Hanafiah and Bortel, 2015  ###reference_b72###) generates codes from the data itself; hybrid deductive-inductive coding (Fereday and Muir-Cochrane, 2006b  ###reference_b52###) combines both approaches, starting with predefined codes and allowing new codes to emerge from the data concurrently.
Qualitative coding plays a crucial role in understanding complex human experiences, behaviors, and psychological constructs. Through the systematic examination of qualitative data, researchers can gain deep insights into the thoughts, emotions, and motivations that drive human actions (Saldana, 2016  ###reference_b140###). Moreover, qualitative analysis allows researchers to explore the rich tapestry of human experience across various domains (Busetto et al., 2020  ###reference_b19###). This approach is valuable in the field of psychology, where understanding the intricacies of human cognition and behavior is essential for developing effective interventions and treatments (Smith and Osborn, 2015  ###reference_b147###).
However, analyzing complex qualitative data is a challenging task that requires significant time, effort, and expertise (Leeson et al., 2019  ###reference_b101###). The process of coding, categorizing, and interpreting qualitative data is often labor-intensive and demands a high level of analytical skills and subject matter knowledge from researchers (Passerello et al., 2019  ###reference_b130###). To address these challenges, technological methods and tools are needed to assist in the qualitative analysis process. Advanced technologies like Natural Language Processing (NLP) (Nelson et al., 2021  ###reference_b125###) and LLMs (Drápal et al., 2023  ###reference_b44###) might potentially support these activities.

LLMs have gained the attention of researchers, with applications in domains such as education (Prather et al., 2023  ###reference_b133###) and potential for future exploration in fields such as sociology, psychology and other social sciences (Demszky et al., 2023  ###reference_b41###). Recent trends focus on the potential of LLMs as text data annotators (He et al., 2023  ###reference_b75###), as they have shown promise in text classification tasks (Sun et al., 2023  ###reference_b151###). Previous studies found that LLMs could outperform MTurk in tasks such as relevance determination and topic detection (Alizadeh et al., 2023  ###reference_b4###; Gilardi et al., 2023  ###reference_b60###), and perform well in zero-shot tasks, such as labeling COVID-19 vaccination-related social media data (Tekumalla and Banda, 2023  ###reference_b154###).
They were also used in automatic genre identification (Kuzman et al., 2023  ###reference_b97###), outperforming fine-tuned models on unseen datasets, and demonstrated potential to label misinformation (Hoes et al., 2023  ###reference_b81###).
Despite the already demonstrated performance of LLMs, their ability to handle subjective tasks crucial for examine social phenomena has been explored. These tasks, known to be challenging even for humans, include data annotation in various domains such as stance detection, sentiment analysis, hate speech, and bot detection (Zhu et al., 2023  ###reference_b175###). The results suggest LLMs’ effectiveness in these tasks. Further research (Huang et al., 2023  ###reference_b85###) has shown LLMs’ potential in tasks requiring analyzing of social norms and cultural context, like detecting implicit hate speech. Similarly, LLMs have shown high accuracy and reliability in annotating political Twitter messages (Törnberg, 2023  ###reference_b157###). Amin et al. (Amin et al., 2023  ###reference_b7###) also found LLMs to be versatile and high-performing in tasks like personality prediction, feelings analysis, and suicide tendency detection, without specialized training.
Current research has made significant progress in using LLMs for text classification tasks. However, these efforts often lack theoretically-grounded qualitative analysis, which can limit the depth and scope of theoretical findings derived from the data (Huang et al., 2023  ###reference_b85###). By focusing primarily on conceptualization-agnostic classifications, existing studies may not fully exploit the potential significance and intrinsic relationships within the data. Furthermore, emphasizing classification performance while neglecting the annotation process itself can hinder effective conceptualization, potentially diminishing the overall theoretical contribution of the research.
To address this limitation, qualitative coding (Lazar et al., 2017  ###reference_b98###) can compensate for the lack of theoretical insights and deeper analysis. Qualitative coding is typically guided by specific conceptual coding schemes, enabling a more profound and comprehensive understanding of the inherent meanings and interconnections within the data.
LLMs have the potential to perform qualitative coding, such as aiding the understanding of complex psychological constructs, offering insights into nuanced relationships and latent structures through their vast knowledge. For instance, attribution models (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###) that aim to explain perceived causes of behavior could benefit from the rich contextual information captured by LLMs.
Consequently, it is crucial to investigate whether LLMs can be leveraged for qualitative coding, a classification approach rooted in conceptual groundings. Such an investigation could potentially empower researchers to derive more conceptually-rich findings from the vast textual data processed by LLMs.

When performing deductive coding, researchers typically adhere to a comprehensive codebook to ensure that the coding is aligned with the predefined characteristics or constructed concepts being applied (Tai et al., 2024  ###reference_b152###).
Manual methods for deductive coding, such as iterating in the codebook and data coding, are time-consuming and resource-intensive, particularly for large datasets (W. Bradley McKibben and Wahesh, 2022  ###reference_b162###). With technological advancements, computer-assisted methods like dictionary-based approaches and machine learning have emerged (Nelson et al., 2021  ###reference_b125###). These methods promise efficiency, enabling the analysis of larger, diverse datasets and the detection of nuanced patterns (Christian Baden and Yarchi, 2020  ###reference_b27###). The advent of LLMs has further enhanced the processes of deductive content analysis.
Recent studies have shown the potential of LLMs in deductive coding tasks. Xiao et al. (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###) found a fair to substantial agreement between human experts and LLMs when using expert-developed codebooks. Similar conclusions have been drawn in previous studies (Dunivin, 2024  ###reference_b45###; Kirsten et al., 2024  ###reference_b96###) indicating that for certain codebooks, LLMs are capable of effectively conducting large-scale content analysis. Tai et al. (Tai et al., 2024  ###reference_b152###) demonstrated that LLMs to identify the presence of codes in a given sample text and provide supporting evidence, concluding that LLM analysis can support qualitative researchers by deductively coding transcripts in a systematic and reliable manner. Hou et al. (Hou et al., 2024a  ###reference_b83###) found that prompt engineering techniques can improve agreement between expert and LLM-coded data. However, Bano et al. (Bano et al., 2023  ###reference_b13###) found low agreement between LLMs and human coders, attributing this to humans relying on personal experiences and LLMs on word choices. Similarly, Ashwin et al. (Ashwin et al., 2023  ###reference_b11###) suggest that using LLMs can lead to significant bias because they overpredict many codes, which can be thought of as the LLM bringing the preconceptions.
Although prior studies have showcased the capabilities of LLMs in a range of content analysis tasks that require deductive coding, the main focus has been on the accuracy of LLMs and the degree to which they code correctly, with less emphasis on the elements that lead to disagreements. To address this, only a few studies (Zambrano et al., 2023  ###reference_b173###; Chew et al., 2023  ###reference_b23###) have made initial efforts to refine code wording based on the differences observed between human coders and LLM coders. These studies suggested methodological structures to enhance code definitions for more accurate deductive coding. Nevertheless, depending solely on the discrepancies between humans and LLMs to refine the code wording might not be adequate. LLMs hold the potential to work in tandem with human researchers on complex research tasks, thanks to their impressive abilities, such as the capacity to identify linguistic nuances (Yan et al., 2024  ###reference_b171###). This can be beneficial in several ways, such as discovering and defining new constructs and conceptualizing new findings. Considering the potential of LLMs, it is necessary to gain a deeper understanding from the perspective of disagreements between humans and LLMs.

Inductive coding, a qualitative coding method, aids in this process by interpreting raw text-based data to identify patterns and construct ideas, independent of existing conceptualization or hypotheses (Boyatzis, 1998  ###reference_b17###).
Initially, inductive coding process involved manually finding observations from the data, deriving patterns, forming hypotheses, and finally conceptualizing the phenomenon (Richards and Hemphill, 2022  ###reference_b137###). Subsequently, several computer-assisted methods emerged to facilitate inductive coding for researchers, including platforms such as Atlas.ti (Sas et al., 2016  ###reference_b141###), MaxQDA222https://www.maxqda.com  ###reference_www.maxqda.com###, nVivo333https://lumivero.com/products/nvivo/nvivo-product-tour/  ###reference_product-tour/###, and nCoder (Zambrano et al., 2023  ###reference_b173###). Additionally, various NLP-based techniques have been developed to assist in this process, such as topic modeling (Lennon et al., 2021  ###reference_b102###), a computer-assisted inductive coding procedure that includes the detection of code patterns (Nelson, 2020  ###reference_b124###), and clustering methods (Parfenova, 2024  ###reference_b129###). The emergence of LLMs has further advanced inductive coding.
Research has shown that LLMs can support inductive coding by generating, searching, and uncovering themes (Hingle et al., 2023  ###reference_b79###; Drápal et al., 2023  ###reference_b44###; Islam and Goldwasser, 2024  ###reference_b88###). Their performance, evaluated comparable human-led coding on the same datasets, proved their ability to deduce the most of primary themes from previous studies (De Paoli, 2023  ###reference_b40###; Dai et al., 2023b  ###reference_b38###). Furthermore, LLMs have been found to be a superior alternative to traditional qualitative coding and conventional NLP techniques (Gamieldien et al., 2023  ###reference_b58###).
While studies show that LLMs can help in proposing codes and themes from interview transcripts, their utility is limited with large datasets. Previous approaches often involved directly feeding large volumes of data into LLMs without a systematic methodology, which might not be suitable for massive data (De Paoli, 2023  ###reference_b40###) due to LLMs’ input length limitations. In such situations, humans still need to manually process and analyze the large amounts of data, which is laborious.
Additionally, previous studies have primarily focused on distinguishing relatively obvious topics (Islam and Goldwasser, 2024  ###reference_b88###), but identifying inner attributions and constructs requires a deeper level of social awareness, presenting a more challenging endeavor that has not been extensively explored.
Thus, exploring new ways of human-LLM collaboration could help address both the data quantity burden and the increased analytical complexity when conceptualizing such nuanced constructs.

sections.section_name: 2.3.3. Hybrid Approach of Inductive and Deductive Coding
sections.text:
The hybrid approach to inductive and deductive coding is a powerful qualitative analysis method that combines the strengths of both top-down and bottom-up coding strategies (Fereday and Muir-Cochrane, 2006b  ###reference_b52###). This approach involves starting with a set of predefined codes based on existing conceptual frameworks, while also allowing new codes and themes to emerge from the data itself. By integrating these two complementary techniques, researchers can build on established theoretical foundations while remaining open to discovering novel insights grounded in the specific context of the study (Hamad et al., 2016  ###reference_b69###). This hybrid method represents an indispensable and integral component of qualitative analysis and enables a more comprehensive and flexible analysis of qualitative data.
Although LLMs have been preliminarily applied in deductive and inductive coding, their application in the hybrid coding approach remains underexplored. To date, no research has incorporated LLMs or other AI techniques into the process of hybrid qualitative analysis, resulting in a research gap between human-LLM synergy and the potential for advanced conceptual insights derived from qualitative analysis using a hybrid approach.
Filling this gap is crucial, as it can complement the impact of the human-LLM collaboration paradigm on advancing qualitative analysis and conceptual development using this novel approach.
Our research endeavors to close this gap by introducing a harmonious human-LLM collaboration paradigm that tackles the absence of LLM assistance in hybrid approach of deductive and inductive coding, thereby advancing the technology-supported qualitative analysis. We propose a methodology that deftly combines the strengths of human researchers and LLMs, leveraging their complementary abilities to uncover profound conceptual insights. This approach could simultaneously address the limitations of previous studies, which often lacked depth in their conceptualized and qualitative findings and placed a substantial burden on human researchers.

Qualitative data collection, a crucial first step in qualitative analysis, significantly impacts data quality. Several methods exist, including interviews, focus groups, and chatbot interactions (Asensio-Cuesta et al., 2021  ###reference_b10###; Casas et al., 2018  ###reference_b21###; Erazo et al., 2020  ###reference_b47###). However, these methods may elicit social desirability bias, especially when dealing with sensitive information (Henderson et al., 2012  ###reference_b77###; Li et al., 2023  ###reference_b105###; Michaels and Corrigan, 2013  ###reference_b118###). Although chatbots can induce socially desirable responses (Schick et al., 2022  ###reference_b142###), people tend to disclose more sensitive information to them compared to humans (Schuetzler et al., 2018  ###reference_b143###). Chatbot-assisted data collection outperforms traditional survey methods by eliciting more detailed information, enhancing engagement (Brahim Zarouali and de Vreese, 2023  ###reference_b18###). Compared to human interviews, this approach also offers several advantages, including increased anonymity, mitigation of interviewer bias, improved standardization, and reduced costs (Kaywan et al., 2021  ###reference_b93###; Podrazhansky et al., 2020  ###reference_b132###; Alkoudmani et al., 2023  ###reference_b5###; Fenza et al., 2023  ###reference_b50###). Based on these advantages of conversational agent-assisted data collection, this study developed a chatbot to act as a virtual interviewer and ask questions.
Interviewees’ self-disclosure during an interview is crucial for obtaining high-quality, insightful data. Self-disclosure, is an act of sharing personal information, thoughts, feelings, and vulnerabilities with others (Collins and Miller, 1994  ###reference_b30###). Recent studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of chatbots in promoting self-disclosure by emulating human-to-human interactions (Lee et al., 2020  ###reference_b100###). Chatbots equipped with self-disclosure capabilities have been shown to influence users’ perceptions and emotions (Ho et al., 2018  ###reference_b80###).
Drawing inspiration from previous works, our study aims to employ a chatbot with self-disclosure to understand participants’ opinions. By utilizing the chatbot’s neutral self-disclosure, we seek to avoid manipulating participants’ opinions and elicit more extensive disclosure from them. This approach helps to efficiently collect a large keystone dataset, which is essential for reducing bias (Demszky et al., 2023  ###reference_b41###) and facilitating deeper understanding in qualitative analysis.

sections.section_name: 3. CHALET: Collaborative Human-LLM AnaLysis for Empowering Conceptualization in QualiTative Research
sections.text:
To bridge the gap in understanding the role of LLM-assisted qualitative coding in advancing qualitative analysis and conceptualization, we thereby made an initial foray into exploring it. We proposed a novel methodological framework,  CHALET, which leverages a hybrid qualitative analysis approach that specifically focuses on the synergistic interplay between human researchers and LLMs. We illustrate our methodological framework in Figure 2  ###reference_###.
Based on this, we elaborate on each step of the proposed  CHALET framework in the following sections. Our approach addresses the limitations of previous qualitative analysis approaches by eliminating temporal and geographical constraints in qualitative data collection, generating insights from human-LLM discrepancies, and overcoming the cost constraints of conceptualization in large datasets.
To guide and introduce our proposed methodology, we have designed the following questions:
###figure_4### ###figure_5### Q1: How is the quality of the large-scale dataset collected through human-chatbot interaction?
Q2: How can human-established deductive coding schemes be effectively integrated into LLM-assisted coding to improve the model’s interpretation and application of these schemes?
Q3: How can the discrepancies between human coding and LLM-assisted coding be identified and analyzed in the hybrid coding framework?
Q4: What richer qualitative insights can be gained by reconciling human-LLM coding disagreements through inductive coding?

We aim to acquire qualitative data from participants and conducting content analysis.
Inspired by the current trend of using chatbots to collect data and the finding that chatbots have been proven to enhance people’s self-disclosure (Lee et al., 2020  ###reference_b100###), we employ a human-chatbot conversation approach to simulate interviews. By utilizing an LLM-enabled chatbot to facilitate interviews, we can collect rich and informative data more efficiently, without the constraints of time and location. This LLM-powered data collection mechanism, with the chatbot’s carefully curated questions aligned with a coding framework, enables the collection of data where each message corresponds to a specific code, facilitating qualitative coding.
AI has been widely adopted for data collection. This paper primarily focuses on the data collection methodologies enabled by LLM-powered chatbots. Techniques like gamification (te Pas et al., 2020  ###reference_b153###) and humanization (Rhim et al., 2022  ###reference_b136###) can transform survey questions into engaging chatbot interactions. Vignettes (Abdullah and Brown, 2020  ###reference_b2###) can be also employed to contextualize the questions within relevant scenarios. By employing a well-structured vignette-to-question flow, we showcase a demonstrative case of human-chatbot interaction for survey questionnaires.

After data collection, we used a synergistic deductive coding approach involving both human coders and LLM coders. Initially, human deductive coding was conducted to serve as a basis for developing and obtaining a codebook. Subsequently, we devised a method to transform the human-generated codebook into a set of instructions that could be provided to the LLM. This approach facilitated the LLM’s ability to identify the constructs within the content, enabling it to perform deductive coding accurately and in closer alignment with human coders.
This process involved both human coders and LLM coders to code the same set of messages, facilitating an in-depth comparison and qualitative analysis of their coding results, ultimately achieving a synergistic collaboration between human and LLM coders.

Initially, human coders engage in qualitative retrospective analysis, deductive coding (Saldana, 2016  ###reference_b140###), anchored in the collected data and the conceptual framework. Methodologically, the process begins with identifying key concepts from the conceptual framework and developing a preliminary codebook to maximize inter-rater reliability (Clarke et al., 2023  ###reference_b28###) and coding coherence. The codebook includes code names, definitions, qualifiers, exclusions (Fereday and Muir-Cochrane, 2006a  ###reference_b51###), and examples (Neuendorf, 2017  ###reference_b126###), serving as a guide throughout the process (Boyatzis, 1998  ###reference_b17###) and evolving during the early stages of the analysis. Following prior practices (Warner et al., 2019  ###reference_b164###; Chopra et al., 2021  ###reference_b26###), at least two primary coders systematically apply the finalized prior codes to the entire dataset, resolving disagreements through open discussion with an additional researcher and consulting a domain specialist if needed. An initial coding step on a subset of data refines the codebook, followed by iterative codebook refinement at checkpoints until inter-rater reliability is met. After coding the entire dataset, a stratified sampling recheck mechanism is applied to ensure coding consistency, reinforcing the validity, reliability, and trustworthiness of the coding process.
###figure_6### ###figure_7### This figure illustrates..

To train LLMs as skillful coders capable of dissecting the constructs and contents, the curated and finalized codebook during the human deductive coding step serves as a suitable training material. This can form the basis for the content of the LLM prompts (Xiao et al., 2023b  ###reference_b168###).
Understanding the outcomes of different prompts and finding an optimal prompt are crucial. The closer the alignment between LLM and human deductive coding results, the more desirable, as it indicates that the LLM has learned coding methodologies akin to a trained human coder and performs them well.
Notably, unlike previous studies (Chew et al., 2023  ###reference_b23###), we do not consider human-generated codes as ground truth, but we aim for LLMs to accurately learn the coding scheme set up by humans and replicate human-generated codes, thereby enhancing inter-rater reliability. Tangentially, finding the optimal prompt is also necessary to minimize the influence of model suboptimality on our decision and analysis of codes. We aim to reduce suboptimality to avoid errors caused by inadequate prompts that lead to the LLMs’ misinterpretation, which may result in biased analyses. To this end, it is hence imperative to design an exploration aimed at searching the prompt space to find the optimal prompt that maximizes inter-rater reliability between LLM and human coding.
To determine the optimal amount of information for LLM coding, we systematically investigate the impact of incorporating various elements of the codebook, such as code definitions, keywords, coding rules, and examples, into the LLM instructions. Furthermore, we explore whether providing additional information beyond the codebook enhances the LLM’s coding performance. This exploration allows us to identify the most effective combination of codebook-derived information and supplementary details to construct prompts that yield the best LLM coding results. We also fine-tune the model parameters and textual structures to achieve optimality, which allows for a more fine-grained modulation compared to previous works (Reiss, 2023  ###reference_b135###). Finally, to ensure the interpretability of LLM coding results, we enable the LLM to output brief justifications for its assigned codes.
Once the optimal prompt is identified and high inter-rater reliability between human and LLM coding is achieved, we can proceed to code the remaining parts of the dataset not coded by humans using the LLM. This is followed by sampling to check if consistency between human and LLM coding is maintained (Ashwin et al., 2023  ###reference_b11###), thus creating a thoroughly scrutinized dataset. Given that model predictions are substantially less time and cost prohibitive compared to human coding, this step provides the greatest relief from heavy workloads relative to traditional content analysis methods. Most of the coding work can now be done by the model rather than by human coders.

After the completion of both human deductive coding and LLM deductive coding (the two steps mentioned above), for each message in a subset of the data, there exists a human code along with multiple LLM codes corresponding to different prompts. Most messages may be coded with at least one LLM code that matches the human code.
We then identify the subset of messages where all LLM codes are mismatched with the human code. Any message with at least one LLM code matching the human code is excluded from the disagreement discussion because such messages likely indicate disagreement due to model suboptimality. Thus, we only select the messages in which none of the prompt variants enables agreement between LLM and humans.
Subsequently, for cases of disagreement between human and LLM codes (hereafter as human-LLM disagreement), all researchers independently review the data and engage in open discussion for further qualitative analysis, aiming to achieve more agreement. All coders are required to provide their opinions on each message involved in human-LLM disagreement:
Human Coding Error: During human deductive coding, coders made incorrect decisions.
LLM Coding Error: Alternatively, the human-LLM disagreement may stem from LLM error, indicating insufficient model performance leading to difficulty in coding certain messages, particularly those with complex or implicit patterns.
New Code: It is also plausible that the human-LLM disagreement signals a novel theme that has not been discussed before. Both human and LLM have erred, indicating that the current coding scheme cannot cover the theme present in the message.
If the coders, after open discussion, suggest that the disagreement may shed light on a novel conceptual perspective, systematic inductive coding is conducted to determine the conceptualization of the patterns therein.

The inductive coding process, rooted in grounded theory principles (Glaser and Strauss, 2017  ###reference_b61###), involves interacting with data, conducting comparative analyses and synthesis (Lazar et al., 2017  ###reference_b98###). The process facilitates the conceptualization of the empirical data. We adhere to a three-step coding procedure: pre-coding, refinement of concepts, and grouping and concept formation.
The inductive coding protocol can be employed collaboratively with LLMs (De Paoli, 2023  ###reference_b40###), leveraging their capabilities to generate codes from messages and synthesize themes from codes.
To align with previous practices (Jardine et al., 2024  ###reference_b90###; Xiao et al., 2023a  ###reference_b167###), firstly, three coders independently record any piquing observations and recurring patterns from participants’ messages through preliminary jotting and connecting related insights. This is followed by open discussions for collective review and conceptualization of these observations by sharing remarks about the commonalities among participants. Upon identifying an observation, a preliminary name is assigned, and this iterative process continues until all data have been examined. Subsequently, these findings and names are conceptualized into high-level concepts. Further discussions and affinity diagramming (Harboe and Huang, 2015  ###reference_b73###) are then conducted to determine the grouping of codes, conceptualizing these into sub-themes and ultimately forming high-level hypotheses.
These newly discovered themes and their sub-themes offer fresh insights that enrich our understanding of the concept under investigation.
In sum, LLM’s pivotal role enables us to pinpoint human-LLM disagreements through deductive coding and apply inductive coding to these messages to discover new themes. The proposed methodology harnesses the power of human-LLM collaboration to generate novel insights, thereby advancing qualitative analysis.

sections.section_name: 4. Case Study: Advancing Qualitative Analysis of Mental-Illness Stigma
sections.text:
We conducted a case study to perform a qualitative analysis on psychological constructs, using social stigma as a representative example, following the  CHALET framework.
We structured our work into three primary steps, including chatbot-assisted data collection, human-LLM synergistic deductive coding, and collaborative inductive coding.
###figure_8###

Attribution model is one of the conceptualization used to understand human psychological constructs.
Although the attribution model has had an enduring influence and frequent application over the past two decades, newer constructs have continually emerged. These constructs often providing fresh insights into social stigma toward individuals with mental illness that do not entirely overlap with the attribution model.
Recent studies (Ong et al., 2020  ###reference_b127###; Subu et al., 2021  ###reference_b150###; Hanafiah and Bortel, 2015  ###reference_b72###) demonstrate that different approaches and conceptual findings can emerge when investigating various populations.
Consequently, it remains unclear whether the attribution model is controversial, inadequate, or ambiguous (Murphy, 2014  ###reference_b122###), thereby necessitating further qualitative analysis. Our work aims to obtain new revelations through the practice of hybrid qualitative coding, employing the paradigm of human-LLM synergy.

In the mental-illness stigma context, the attribution model (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###) is a well-designed and widely applied conceptual framework proposed to explore the factors contributing to the emergence of social stigma. Our case study builds on the foundation of the attribution model, which includes three dimensions: personal responsibility belief, emotional responses, and behavioral responses.
The attribution model suggests that people’s perceptions of the extent to which a person with a mental illness is responsible for their condition can lead to stigmatized emotional responses, such as lack of pity, anger, and fear. These emotional responses can further elicit discriminatory behavioral responses, including coercion, segregation, social distance, and withdrawal of help.
Social stigma, originally defined by Goffman (Goffman, 1964  ###reference_b62###), is a mark or attribute that diminishes an individual, transforming them from a complete and ordinary person into one who is tainted and devalued. It is observed when an individual possesses or is perceived to possess a characteristic that implies a devalued social identity within a specific context (Crocker et al., 1998  ###reference_b36###). It comprises stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###). Our qualitative analysis mainly focused on public stigma, which arises when a significant portion of the population endorses negative stereotypes (Marcelin et al., 2019  ###reference_b114###). Social stigma is a prevalent issue among individuals with mental illness (Corrigan and Shapiro, 2010  ###reference_b34###), which hinders their opportunities, self-determination, and recovery (Corrigan and Shapiro, 2010  ###reference_b34###; Overton and Medina, 2008  ###reference_b128###).

The data collection procedure included a short online questionnaire, which was used to recruit participants for an interactive conversation session with an LLM-enabled conversational agent that represents a specific scenario in human-LLM communication. Data collection for this study ran between November 2023 and February 2024.

Vignettes (Link et al., 2004  ###reference_b108###), brief evocative stories, are effective tools for eliciting opinions and attitudes toward individuals with mental illness in conversational agent-mediated social contact (Kim et al., 2020  ###reference_b95###; Sebastian and Richards, 2017  ###reference_b144###; Lee et al., 2023  ###reference_b99###), as they provide detailed stimuli that resonate with participants’ experiences (Marwaha and Livingston, 2002  ###reference_b117###) while avoiding excessively emotionally charged situations (Gourlay et al., 2014  ###reference_b66###). We designed a vignette based on DSM-5 (Association, 2013  ###reference_b12###), as shown in Figure 6  ###reference_###, which focused on Avery, a person experiencing depressive symptoms. The vignette described Avery’s symptoms without using technical or medical jargon, and did not explicitly specify Avery’s gender or age. It illustrated how the symptoms negatively impacted various aspects of Avery’s life, including academics, work, relationships, and interactions with others. To represent the most common symptoms, we avoided including more extreme symptoms such as self-harm or suicide.

During the study, after the participants read the vignette, chatbot posed questions based on the vignette’s content to understand their opinions. The strong capability and flexibility of LLMs could allow us to ask the questions in a vivid manner. To collect qualitative data for each attribution in the original attribution model (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###) and then gain a deeper understanding, we designed multiple questions corresponding to the various attributions outlined in the model. Our chatting questions were adapted from the 27-item Attribution Questionnaire (AQ-27) (Corrigan, 2012  ###reference_b31###; Armstrong, 2003  ###reference_b9###), which is frequently employed to measure people’s stigmatization levels in both HCI and psychological practices (Ihalainen-Tamlander et al., 2016  ###reference_b86###; Lee et al., 2023  ###reference_b99###; Werner et al., 2012  ###reference_b166###). The questions we used to collect qualitative data are presented in Table 1  ###reference_###. Our materials were reviewed and collaboratively refined by a social work specialist within the research team and a professional psychiatrist. We adapt the original questionnaire to fit the context of our chatbot’s questions. The detailed adaption can be found in Appendix A.1.2  ###reference_.SSS2###.

We utilized the UChat444https://uchat.au/  ###reference_uchat.au/### platform to build our LLM-powered conversational agent. We employed a hybrid approach for implementation, where the text delivered by the agent can originate from pre-written scripts or be generated by prompting an LLM. The small talk questions, vignette delivery, questions corresponding to the attribution model (Corrigan et al., 2003  ###reference_b33###), and the chatbot’s neutral self-disclosure for each question were pre-scripted and hardcoded into the system. Other text elements, such as follow-up questions and active responses to participants, were generated by LLM. Examples of our prompts for follow-up questions can be found in A.1.4  ###reference_.SSS4###. We employed gpt-4-1106-preview555https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/overview  ###reference_erview### to generate our chatbot’s text, setting the maximum tokens to 100 and the temperature to 0.2666We experimented with different temperature values and discovered that higher temperatures caused the model to generate a wider variety of follow-up question texts. However, this led to less controllable questions, which confused some participants in our pilot study. Therefore, we opted for a lower temperature to ensure that the model consistently generated similar and reliable questions.. Our interface was embedded into the Qualtrics777https://www.qualtrics.com/  ###reference_www.qualtrics.com/### study. We ensured that the concurrency rate did not exceed 50.

We recruited participants from diverse backgrounds, including various age groups and educational background, through online platforms. During the recruitment process, we clearly outlined the study’s general scope, duration, and participants’ right to withdraw at any point. Our recruitment criteria regulated that all participants must 1) be 21 years or older, 2) have English as their first language, 3) be willing to read materials related to mental illness, and 4) participants were required not to have immediate and urgent mental health concerns. We incorporated the last criterion due to the potential risk that the vignettes about mental illness could cause distress to individuals grappling with such issues (Roberts, 2002  ###reference_b138###).
Ultimately, we recruited 1,002 participants, none of whom reported having an ongoing mental illness. The average age of the participants was 46.38 (). Detailed participant characteristics are presented in Table 2  ###reference_###.
###table_1###

The one-time study lasted approximately 30 minutes, for which the participants received a reimbursement of about 6.3 USD for their time.
Initially, we obtained participants’ consent, informing them that their personal data would remain confidential. Participants were forewarned that the study would involve a mental illness-related scenario and were given the option to quit if uncomfortable. Subsequently, the participants were asked basic demographic questions.
The participants then engaged in a conversation with the conversational agent for approximately 20 minutes.
After the conversation, a debriefing session was conducted, during which participants were informed about common types of stigma, and the researchers’ objective of assessing participants’ stigma attitudes was explained.

To ensure reliable coding results and mitigate human bias, we implemented triangulation. We had multiple diverse researchers independently code and analyze the data, and collected data from different times, spaces, and groups. These triangulation approaches effectively reduced the impact of inherent human bias on the coding results. Firstly, two coders independently conducted pilot coding using the initial codebook, coding 70 messages, with 10 messages for each attribution. After independently coding, we engaged in open discussions about these 70 messages, reached agreements, and subsequently established initial and applicable rules.
We then proceeded to the formal coding stage, involving a third coder and providing necessary training. The codebook refinement followed, where we randomly selected 700 messages from 100 participants for coding. Two coders independently coded the messages and set up frequent checkpoints: after coding 10 participants (Cohen’s ), then another 10 participants (Cohen’s ), followed by four sets of 20 participants each (Cohen’s , 0.79, 0.76, and 0.72, respectively). Coders openly discussed the codebook to ensure consistency, adding empirically-derived rules, revising definitions, and including keywords for each code. Finally, when the inter-rater reliability among coders reached a satisfactory level, we continued meeting with the specialist in the research team to finalize the codebook. We followed the specialist’s advice and set up longer checkpoints after finalization: coding 50 participants (Cohen’s ), then another 50 participants (Cohen’s ), followed by 100 participants (Cohen’s ), and two sets of 150 participants each (Cohen’s  and 0.66, respectively). We completed the coding of 600 participants’ messages, totaling 4,200 messages (Cohen’s ). Upon completion, we consulted with the specialist in the research team to confirm the codes for messages where the three coders had not reached an agreement. This concluded the human deductive coding process, outputting both the human codes and the development of the coding scheme.

Henceforth, based on the aforementioned human deductive coding established coding scheme, we enabled the LLM to follow the proposed coding scheme for deductive coding and evaluate its performance by coding the same messages as the human coders.
To demonstrate the performance and to find the prompt that maximizes the inter-rater reliability between LLM and human coders, we conducted experiments around prompt design, drawing inspiration from previous practices (Dunivin, 2024  ###reference_b45###; He et al., 2024  ###reference_b76###; Hou et al., 2024b  ###reference_b84###). We designed the following three aspects of exploration and comparison, with all experiments using the inherently high-performing gpt-4-1106-preview. Previous research on prompt design is inspired by techniques such as role prompting (Reiss, 2023  ###reference_b135###; Törnberg, 2024  ###reference_b159###), where a role is assigned (e.g., “Your role is a competent coder for social stigma toward mental illness”). We applied this technique consistently in our experiments.
Which aspects of the codebook are necessary when leveraging LLM for deductive coding? Firstly, as the prompt content originates from the human-written codebook, the components can be divided into several parts: code names, keywords, additional rules (refer to Section A.2.1  ###reference_.SSS1###), and examples for all codes. Additionally, it includes the vignette as background knowledge, the question from Table 1  ###reference_###, and the participants’ messages. We investigated whether all information, originally provided to humans in the codebook, is useful for LLM deductive coding and if each piece of information contributes to increased inter-rater reliability between the LLM and humans, or if the presence of certain information may lead to information overload and have a negative effect.
Therefore, we systematically controlled the presence or absence of each component within the codebook. Furthermore, we compared the performance under two distinct information quantity scenarios: prompts containing all code information (eight codes) and prompts containing only the target code. The latter approach was inspired by previous work (Dunivin, 2024  ###reference_b45###), where we provided only the code corresponding to the question associated with the message in the prompt, along with the Non-stigmatized code. All other attributions of stigmatization were categorized as Stigmatized (others), effectively modeling the coding process as a three-class classification task.
Is there a need for additional information, and if so, how impactful is its inclusion? Secondly, we explored whether additional content beyond the codebook is necessary and if it can further improve performance (Tai et al., 2024  ###reference_b152###). Previous research has demonstrated the usefulness of chain-of-thought prompting (Wei et al., 2022  ###reference_b165###), where a complex reasoning task is decomposed into sub-tasks, and the model is instructed to perform the sub-tasks sequentially. The original human-written codebook does not provide the reasoning process. We investigated whether the reasoning process can help the LLM code messages more consistent with humans. Additionally, in-context learning has proven beneficial in NLP tasks (Dong et al., 2022  ###reference_b42###), so we also explored whether increasing the number of examples is helpful. Moreover, previous papers have shown that the order of examples in the prompt can affect LLM performance (Lu et al., 2022  ###reference_b112###). Therefore, we conducted this part of the experiment under the condition of only having target-code information, i.e., adjusting the order of examples for the three codes: Stigmatized, Non-stigmatized, and Stigmatized (Others), to investigate the impact of example order.
Are there any additional settings of the model that are impactful? Lastly, we experimented on whether different model parameters or other LLM settings, unrelated to the amount of information, significantly affect the results. Inspired by Ziems et al. (Ziems et al., 2024  ###reference_b176###), we explored the impact of the order of instruction and content on the results. Following (Reiss, 2023  ###reference_b135###), we investigated the effect of the temperature settings on the results. Similarly, we explored and compared three temperature conditions: 1, 0.5, and 0. By integrating these various aspects of exploration, we searched the prompt space for the optimal prompt to achieve optimal performance and find the highest agreement between the LLM and human coders, thereby facilitating the interpretive capabilities of LLM coders and minimizing the impact of model suboptimality on the analysis.
Finally, when the agreement between the LLM and human coders reaches a satisfactory level, we can utilize the LLM to code the remaining data. As previous works have found that using LLMs for qualitative coding may introduce bias (Ashwin et al., 2023  ###reference_b11###; Zhu et al., 2023  ###reference_b175###), after completing the LLM deductive coding on data not previously coded by humans, we select 25 messages from each attribution, maintaining the deductive approach outlined in Section 4.3.1  ###reference_.SSS1###, and perform human deductive coding to enhance validity.

After identifying the optimal agreement (represented by the highest Cohen’s ) between LLM deductive coding and human deductive coding, indicating that we have achieved a sufficiently high level of agreement, we shifted our focus to the human-LLM disagreement set to further investigate the underlying causes of disagreement.
The previous LLM deductive coding resulted in various prompt designs, corresponding to different coding outputs from the LLM. For each message, there was one human-provided code and multiple codes generated by the LLM. We thereby identified the set of messages where the human code differed from all LLM codes across the various prompts. This approach was taken because even the optimal LLM deductive coding result (which had the highest agreement with humans) may have instances where other coding results with lower human agreement can align with the human code, while the optimal result itself cannot. In other words, despite having the highest overall agreement with humans and undergoing prompt optimization and selection, the optimal LLM deductive coding result may still exhibit suboptimality, leading to disagreements that could be resolved by other LLM results with different prompts. By taking the intersection of human-LLM disagreements across all LLM deductive coding results, we minimized the impact of model suboptimality on our disagreement analysis.
Drawing upon the disagreement resolution methods proposed by Chinh et al. (Chinh et al., 2019  ###reference_b24###), we leveraged an open discussion approach to resolve human-LLM disagreements. We conducted the disagreement-resolving process for each attribution in sequence, engaging in an open discussion throughout to check for any discrepancies in understanding among coders. At this step, three coders independently code the messages and determine whether the disagreement arises from human coding error, LLM coding error, or the emergence of a new code. If the coders, after engaging in open discussion, believe that the disagreement may indicate a new code, it is retained for further exploration in the next step.

Following the paradigm outlined in Section 3.3  ###reference_###,
we conducted inductive coding on messages identified as potentially containing new codes within the human-LLM disagreement dataset. This process was carried out by three coders to ensure reliability. Inspired by prior research on leveraging LLMs for inductive coding (Islam and Goldwasser, 2024  ###reference_b88###), we explored two paradigms: 1) using LLMs to autonomously generate new themes and code, and 2) a human-LLM collaborative approach. After expert review of the new findings produced by each paradigm, we chose to present the results from the human-LLM collaborative paradigm as our final output.
To facilitate collaborative inductive coding, we first review all the data, then independently pre-coded by taking notes and assigning labels. We refined our notes and reached agreement on the codes through open discussions. The agreed-upon codes were incorporated into the affinity diagram (Appendix A.5.2  ###reference_.SSS2###). These sessions allowed for the development and refinement of concepts as we identified emerging patterns from our observations and from LLM-provided output. The iterative refinement process involved evolving patterns as more participant messages were analyzed.
After compiling codes, we engaged in grouping by identifying commonalities and combining similar codes. Throughout several rounds of defining themes and refining code definitions, we engaged in concept formation based on the codebook. Based on the data patterns and the input codes provided, our conceptualization process involved a collaborative approach that combined human researcher’s ideas with LLM-generated ideas.
Following the attribution model, we categorized the codes into cognitive judgment, emotional responses, and behavioral responses. Finally, we discussed our findings, derived from the human-LLM collaboration hybrid qualitative analysis, with domain specialists to validate and finalize our novel insights.

To answer Q1, we analyzed the overall situation and quality of the qualitative data we received. The average time for participants to complete the chatbot conversation was  () minutes. We assigned one question, along with follow-up questions (if any), to each attribution. When answering questions, participants typed an average of 43.82 () words for responsibility, 43.4 () for social distance, 40.86 () for anger, 41.5 () for helping, 39.3 () for pity, 40.18 () for coercion segregation, and 39.74 () for fear, showing they expressed substantial opinions.
The average informativeness score (Xiao et al., 2020b  ###reference_b170###) of the data collected through our chatbot is 87.34 (), indicating a high level of richness. Details on the calculation of the informativeness score can be found in Appendix A.1.5  ###reference_.SSS5###. The specific collected data from participants are presented in Table LABEL:table:ind.
We further validated the quality of the collected data by examining the word frequency in each attribution. As shown in Figure 4  ###reference_###, we found that participants’ discussions with the chatbot closely revolved around the questions posed for each attribution. The frequent appearance of words directly related to the scenario and question, as well as the presence of words reflecting complex emotions and thinking, indicated that our LLM-enabled chatbot effectively facilitated rich conversations about the social stigma of mental illness. Moreover, the results revealed the participants’ engagement and reflection on the topics and issues presented in the scenarios. Further analysis of word frequency is provided in Appendix A.1.6  ###reference_.SSS6###.
###figure_10### This image visually ..
Overall, the data provides a rich and multifaceted exploration of social stigma toward mental illness. The insights and experiences of the participants offer valuable perspectives on this important issue. This further demonstrates that our LLM-enabled chatbot is effective for data collection and can collect diverse, multi-perspective, and rich qualitative data.

Of the total 4,145 messages we coded, 46.00% () of the responses included stigmatized attitudes.
Among the stigmatized codes, the most prevalent was social distance, accounting for 9.14% () of all codes. Responsibility followed closely at 9.51% (), and fear made up 8.88% () of the total codes. Anger and coercion segregation constituted 7.19% () and 6.56% () of the codes, respectively. The least common stigmatized codes were helping at 3.81% () and pity at 1.01% (). In addition, we achieved the following inter-rater reliability scores (Cohen’s ) for human deductive coding on each attribution: responsibility (0.71), anger (0.75), pity (0.36), fear (0.69), helping (0.56), coercion segregation (0.71), and social distance (0.7).
In our deductive coding process, we established rules and achieved consensus among coders through discussions with specialists. We also defined each stigma attribution according to the original model (Appendix A.2.1  ###reference_.SSS1###). Our coding scheme includes seven stigmatized and one non-stigmatized thought, totaling eight codes. The non-stigmatized code represents texts explicitly convey positive sentiments, like sympathy and assistance. For example, P383 considered the hospitalization suggestion offensive, reflecting a non-stigmatized view against coercion and segregation.
“No, I think that is a deeply offensive and appalling suggestion. I think that is a strange question to ask. The real question is what right would anyone have to take her Avery away or hospitalise her against her will? She is harming no one.” (P383)
Table LABEL:table:ind presents the quotes for each stigmatized code. Throughout this, we provide a detailed practice on human deductive coding in the attribution model.

To answer Q2, we conducted three explorations, investigating the utility of the information in the codebook, whether additional information was needed, and the influence of different settings. The findings of these explorations are presented as follows to demonstrate the impact of information amount differences on LLMs’ interpretation of the content to be coded, which, in turn, provide guidance on enhancing LLMs’ ability to analyze the materials we aim to code effectively.
Overall, all information in codebook proves to be valuable - 
We present the results in Table 3  ###reference_###. First, comparing the scenarios where all codes are provided versus only the target code, we observe that information from other codes can assist the LLM in investigating the overall context, potentially improving performance. Consequently, information from other codes is not regarded as noise for the target code.
Second, by examining the impact of different amounts of information from the codebook, we focus on scenarios where only the target code information is available. Vignettes have a minor effect, negatively correlated with the performance of codes that have lower human agreement (pity, helping) or lower LLM agreement (coercion segregation), and positively correlated with the performance of easily classifiable codes. Rules play a vital role for all codes, particularly for attributions with lower human agreement (pity, helping). Inclusion of rules can enable the human-LLM agreement to surpass the human-human agreement. Moreover, both keywords and examples contribute slightly to the improved performance of all codes.

However, there are two exceptions: pity and coercion segregation. Notably, for pity, information from other codes can act as noise. This is empirically observed due to the low sample size with the code Stigmatized (Pity), accounting for only 32 out of 592 instances, and the low human-human agreement, suggesting that the LLM, like a human coder, struggled with edge cases and ambiguous situations, especially where implicit information was required to make a judgment.
For example, “Concern for his situation and we should all be humble to them always. Suddenly anger.” (P523) is a participant’s response to the question about whether they feel pity for Avery.
Coder 1 labeled the message as Stigmatized (pity), suggesting that the pity shown was not genuine, but due to societal expectation and obligation. Coder 2, however, saw it as Non-stigmatized, viewing the pity as sincere. After discussion, it was agreed to classify the message as Non-stigmatized. Despite this, there was a sense of unease, indicating a borderline case between stigma and genuine pity. The coding notably differed from LLM results, where 21 prompts identified it as Stigmatized (pity) and six as other forms of stigma. This discrepancy highlights the controversial nature of this message, with both human coders and LLMs struggling to reach a consensus. This also underscores the need to revisit and refine our coding categories to better capture such complex cases.
For coercion segregation, integrating external code information enhances performance, but additional codebook details may add noise. Excessive information leads to incremental performance gains once again. Vignettes and rules reduce agreement levels. One possible reason is that human coders rely on more than just the codebook; their understanding benefits from collaborative codebook creation, discussions, and oral guidance as well. In contrast, LLMs lack this interactive context and rely solely on written descriptions. Some implicit knowledge obvious to the original coders might be missing from these descriptions (Dunivin, 2024  ###reference_b45###).

An anomaly in helping shows that adding more examples or detailed reasoning decreases performance. This may occur because additional examples extend the input, overwhelming the model with too much information, making it hard to identify crucial details. Additionally, the model’s need to handle multiple tasks like natural language understanding (NLU), reasoning chain planning, and natural language generation (NLG) simultaneously complicates learning.
Table 4  ###reference_### shows that example permutation minimally affects coder-LLM agreement, yet we explored its effect on prediction distribution. This further analysis focuses on the effect of permutation under only target-code information. We quantified the number of predicted samples for each code when providing examples in different orders in prompt. Figure 12  ###reference_### reveals that codes at the beginning are predicted more frequently. For example, positioning the Stigmatized example first results in 278.5 predicted Stigmatized samples, compared to 240.5 when it’s last. This pattern holds for other attributions too.
Temperature has little effect; placing instructions before content when prompting LLMs improves LLM-human coding consistency -
Figure 5  ###reference_### displays the key insights include: temperature has a minimal impact on LLM performance, with lower temperatures slightly enhancing outcomes. Additionally, introducing instructions at the beginning of prompts, followed by the user content, improves performance. These findings highlight the need for tailored instruction design in LLMs, guided by human-created codebooks. Further details on prompt design are in Appendix A.3  ###reference_###.
Our studies show that coding complexity varies for both humans and LLMs across different qualitative analysis codes. Providing LLMs with the full codebook information, including additional rules and examples, etc., is crucial for LLM coding. For challenging codes, extra rules are necessary and can improve performance beyond human coding. Conversely, simpler codes may only need basic definitions. All code information serves as valuable data that aids the LLM in analyzing what it should not learn and classify as the target code. Supplementary information beyond codebook is generally not essential, although a slight impact is observed for codes that are easy for humans to code. Multiple examples alter sample predictions but do not significantly change overall results. Temperature shows no significant effect, and initial clear instructions are advised for LLMs. Ultimately, our research suggests prompt designs that enhance LLMs’ ability to interpret human psychological constructs, leading to more accurate LLM-assisted coding aligned with human interpretations and enriching our understanding of societal and psychological dynamics.
Ultimately, after optimizing the LLMs’ ability to interpret and apply the coding scheme, we achieved results that exhibit the highest agreement with human deductive coding. By consolidating all the aforementioned findings, we identified the optimal agreement (Cohen’s ) between humans and LLMs for each attribution: responsibility (0.7), anger (0.65), pity (0.55), fear (0.71), helping (0.69), coercion segregation (0.58), and social distance (0.76). Upon discovering the optimal prompt for each attribution, we utilized these prompts to code all messages in the dataset that had not been previously coded by humans. Finally, we randomly selected 25 messages from each attribution for validation, resulting in a human-LLM agreement (Cohen’s ) of 0.87, demonstrating the reliability of LLM coding.
